children.name: an exact number, amount, time, etc
exact b1
children.definition: exact an exact number, amount, or time is completely correct and is no more and no less than it should be:
examples: ‘can you tell me the exact time?’ ‘it’s 6.37.’
the exact weight of the baby at birth was 3.2 kg.
you need to give me the exact measurements of the room.
to be exactformalused to after a number to emphasize that what you are saying is exact :
she has worked at the bank for many years, nine to be exact.
it took her about an hour - 58 minutes to be exact.
the exact amount/number/figurei don’t know the exact amount, but it was a lot.
the exact sizefirst, cut a piece of wood about 1cm x 10cm – the exact size doesn’t matter.
the exact datehe plans to retire soon, but the exact date is not fixed.
the exact time/momentat that exact moment, the phone rang.
the exact position/location/spot etcthe satellite pictures showed the enemy’s exact location.
the exact details(= details that are correct in every way )nobody knows the exact details of what happened.
exactly[adverb] a2 use this to emphasize that a number, amount, or time is no more or less than a particular time or figure:
it’s exactly 5 o'clock.
the bill came to exactly $1000.

children.name: precise b2
children.definition: precise precise information is based on clear and exact figures or measurements, especially when it is important that no mistakes are made :
examples: 1precise information, details etc are exact, clear, and correctsyn exact:
precise sales figures
it was difficult to get precise information.
it’s difficult to be precise about the number of deaths caused by smoking.
to be preciseto give precise information or figures
it’s difficult to be precise about the number of deaths caused by smoking.
‘she’s a lot older than you, isn’t she?’ ‘fifteen years, to be precise .’
2[ only before noun ] used to emphasize that you are referring to an exact thingsyn exact:
at that precise moment, her husband walked in.
the precise cause of the disease is unknown.
the precise location of the ship
the precise nature of their agreement
precisely[adverb] b2
at 3 o'clock precisely, the ceremony began.
she couldn’t describe the car very precisely.

children.name: an exact description, translation, copy, etc
exact b1
children.definition: exact an exact copy, model etc of something is like it in every possible way: giống hệt, y chang
examples: an exact replica of a 900-year-old buddhist shrine
i can’t remember her exact words, but this is the gist of what she said.
exact likenessuse this about a painting or drawing of someone that looks very much like that person giống y như đúc
it’s not an exact likeness, but it’s recognisable as my father.
an exact copy/replica(= something which has been made, that is exactly like another thing )the vessel is an exact replica of a viking longboat.
an exact equivalent(= something that has exactly the same meaning, purpose, value etc as something else )there is no exact equivalent in english for the phrase.
an exact match(= something that is exactly the same as something else )the two dna samples were an exact match.
sb’s exact words(= the words someone actually said )try to remember his exact words – it’s very important.
the exact wording(= the words that were used in a letter, speech, etc, with nothing changed )what was the exact wording of the message?
the exact same thing/way etcinformal(= exactly the same thing/way etc )if you’d been there, you’d have done the exact same thing.

children.name: literal c2
children.definition: literal
examples: 1the literal meaning of a word or expression is its basic or original meaning →figurative: gốc, nguyên văn, đen
literal meaning/sense/interpretation etc
a trade war is not a war in the literal sense.
the literal meaning of 'television' is 'seeing from a distance'.
you need to demonstrate to the examiners that you have more than a literal understanding of the text.
2 literal translationa translation that translates each word exactly instead of giving the general meaning in a more natural wayopp free: sát nghĩa, nguyên văn
her translation is too literal, resulting in heavy, unnatural prose.
it’s rare to use a literal translation of a film title when it is sold abroad.
literally[adverb] b2
1according to the most basic or original meaning of a word or expression :
‘vino de tavola' literally means ’table wine'.
the name of the cheese is dolcelatte, literally meaning ‘sweet milk’.
i said i felt like quitting, but i didn’tmeanitliterally(= i did not mean exactly what i said )!
2 take sb/sth literallyto believe exactly what someone or something says rather than trying to understand their general meaning :
she takes the bible literally.
3used to emphasize that something, especially a large number, is actually true :
the olympic games were watched by literally billions of people.
4spokenused to emphasize a strong expression or word that is not being used in its real or original meaning. some people consider this use to be incorrect :
dad was literally blazing with anger.

children.name: word for word c2
children.definition: word for word if you repeat, copy, or translate sth word for word, you use the exact words that are in it: đúng nguyên văn, theo từng chữ một
examples: ▪ he asked me to repeat word for word the instructions he’d just given me.
▪ the footnote gave a word for word translation of the quotation.

children.name: faithful x
children.definition: faithful a faithful copy of sth is as close as possible to the original: “trung thành”
examples: a faithful account of what had happened
afaithful reproductionof the original picture
his model cars are faithful copies of the originals.
this is a faithful interpretation of shakespeare’s original text.
a faithful reconstruction of an anglo-saxon village
faithfully[adverb]
the tv version follows the original novel faithfully.

children.name: strict c2
children.definition: strict exact and correct, often in a way that seems unreasonable, ccording to accepted rules or an accepted system:
examples: dates must be listed in strict chronological order.
under a strict interpretation of the rules, she would be suspended.
in the strictest sense of the word
in the strictest sense of the word, all popular fiction is ‘romantic’.
amy was attractive, although not beautifulin the strictest sense of the word.

children.name: verbatim x
children.definition: verbatim formal repeating the exact words that were spoken or written: nguyên văn
examples: ▪ the government released a verbatim transcript of the pilot’s last words.
▪ he lifted passages almost verbatim from an earlier essay he had written.

children.name: exactly b1
children.definition: exactly use this to give or ask for exact details or information: hoàn toàn đúng
examples: ▪ glue the pieces together, exactly as shown in the diagram.
▪ it took us exactly two hours to get here.
exactly who/what/where etc
▪ the police want to know exactly when you left the building.
▪ the doctors can’t say exactly what’s wrong with my mother.
exactly the same
▪ it tastes exactly the same as meat.
who/what/where exactly?
▪ where exactly are you from?
▪ what exactly did you want to see?

children.name: precisely b2
children.definition: precisely/prɪˈsaɪsli/  exactly - use this when it isimportantto describe something very carefully or to get very exact information: chính xác
examples: precisely what/where/who etc chính xác là cái gì, ai, ở đâu
▪ we need to know precisely how much this is going to cost.
▪ can you tell us more precisely what happened?
where/what/who precisely?chính xác là ở đâu, cái gì, ai?
▪ what precisely do you mean by ‘relativity’?

children.name: just b1
children.definition: just/dʒʌst/  especially spoken use this to say exactly how, what, where etc something is: như
examples: ▪ that’s just the right place for the painting, don’t you think?
just what/how/where etc
▪ a new handbag! that’s just what i wanted.
▪ just who does he think he is, coming in here and shouting like that?
just the same
▪ he and his brother are just the same -- lazy.

children.name: exactly b1
children.definition: exactly/ɪgˈzæktli/  use this toemphasizethat something is the particular thing that youwantormean: chính xác
examples: ▪ this is exactly the kind of job that computers are good at.
▪ that’s exactly the sort of material i’m looking for.
exactly what chính xác như
▪ the earrings are beautiful! they’re exactly what i wanted.
▪ that’s exactly what happened to me!

children.name: precisely b2
children.definition: precisely/prɪˈsaɪsli/  exactly - use this toemphasizeexactly what the situation is, exactly what happened, exactly what you meant etc: đúng
examples: ▪ that is precisely the point i was trying to make earlier.
▪ the new legislation won’t solve the problem - it will do precisely the opposite.

children.name: just b1
children.definition: just/dʒʌst/ informaluse this to talk about exactly the thing, person, or place you mean, want etc: chính là
examples: ▪ we want just the same rights as everyone else.
▪ he said he was leaving her and proceeded to do just that!
just who/what/how etc chính là người, cái gì, thế nào
▪ i’m not sure just who you mean.
▪ mallorca? that’s just where we want to go.

children.name: right b1
children.definition: right/raɪt/  right in/on/up etc use this when something is in an exact position or place: đúng (chỗ)
examples: ▪ that hit me right in the eye!
▪ i got a mosquito bite right on the end of my nose.
▪ there’s the house, right in front of you.
▪ he sat down right beside her.

children.name: smack x
children.definition: smack in the middle of something/smack in front ofsomething/ˌsmæk ɪn ðə ˈmɪdl əv, something, ˌsmæk ɪn ˈfrʌnt əv, something/  informal use this to say that something is exactly in a place, especially when this is unpleasant in some way: trực tiếp
examples: ▪ they live smack in the middle of a huge housing estate.
▪ a garbage truck had parked smack in front of our house.
smack dabamerican use this to emphasize that you are being exact trực tiếp
▪ the ball hit me smack dab in the middle of my forehead.

children.name: bang x
children.definition: bang/bæŋ/  british informal bang in/on/up etc use this when something is in an exact point or position, especially if it falls there: đúng
examples: ▪ he landed bang in the middle of the roof, and it collapsed.
▪ the eraser hit him bang on the top of his head.
right/slap bang đúng vào bên phải, tát đúng vào
▪ the arrow hit the target right bang in the middle.
▪ they’ve put an ornamental fountain slap bang in the middle of the roundabout.

children.name: doing sth in exactly the right way
exactly b1
children.definition: exactly/ɪgˈzæktli/  use this to talk about doing something in exactly the right way: chính xác
examples: ▪ assemble the table exactly as shown in the diagram on the left.
▪ i don’t exactly know how to dry herbs, could you show me?
▪ you must do exactly as i say.

children.name: strictly b2
children.definition: strictly/ˈstrɪktli/  done exactly according to a set of rules or instructions: nghiêm túc
examples: ▪ the work is strictly on a volunteer basis.
▪ the immigration laws have been strictly implemented.
▪ martha and joan kept strictly to their part of the house.

children.name: religiously x
children.definition: religiously/rɪˈlɪdʒəsli/  if you do something religiously, you do it in exactly the way that you are supposed to do it: y như thế
examples: ▪ he counted his money up religiously every night.
▪ julia has been sticking religiously to her diet.

children.name: inaccuracy c1
children.definition: inaccuracy
examples: 1[ countable ] a statement that is not completely correct :
jansen’s review contained several inaccuracies.
the film is full of historical inaccuracies.
2[ uncountable ] a lack of correctness :
as a journalist, you simply cannot tolerate inaccuracy.
the inaccuracy of the missiles greatly diminishes their effectiveness.

children.name: fine c1
children.definition: fineadjectiveexact
examples: [ usually before noun ]very exact and delicate, or needing to be done, treated or considered very carefully
_i understood in general what she was talking about, but some of the finerdetails/pointswere beyond me.
there'safinelinebetween love and hate.

children.name: accuracy b2
children.definition: accuracy the quality of being correct or trueopp inaccuracy
examples: we double checked the figures to ensure their accuracy.
accuracy of
worries about the accuracy of government statistic

children.name: technically c2
children.definition: technicallyadverb
examples: according to an exact understanding of rules, facts, etc.
_technically, the country's economic problems are over but recovery will be slow.
_young people who are technically still children

children.name: strictly speaking b2
children.definition: strictly speaking
examples: being completely accurate
_strictly speaking, great britain consists of scotland,walesandengland, and theunited kingdomconsists ofgreat britainandnorthern ireland.
